I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This  is  an  eligible  transaction  under  the  Faster  Approach  to  Small  Nonsovereign 
Transactions  (FAST)  framework.1 The  transaction  involves  an  equity  investment  of  up  to 
$10,000,000 in Tata Capital Growth Fund II (TCGF II) in India.  
 
2.  TCGF II is a targeted $350 million equivalent Indian rupee private equity fund established 
as a trust under Indian laws and registered as a category II Alternative Investment Fund under 
the Securities and Exchange Board of India Alternative Investment Fund Regulations.2 The 
investment manager and sponsor of TCGF II is Tata Capital Limited (Tata Capital). Through 
TCGF II, Tata Capital proposes to invest primarily equity capital for minority stakes in a portfolio 
of 10−12 mainly lower middle-market companies in India, including small and medium-sized 
enterprises  (SMEs). 3 Focus  sectors  for  the  fund  include  financial  services,  health  care, 
manufacturing, and information technology. Tata Capital does not propose that TCGF II will invest 
in real estate or infrastructure. The climate change impact of the proposed investment is expected 
to be minimal because the renewable energy sector is not a focus.  
 
3.  Through its proposed investment in TCGF II, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
contribute to India’s ongoing economic development (gross domestic product is expected to grow 
by 7.0% in 2019 and 7.2% in 2020) by infusing critical growth capital to well-managed companies 
operating  in  sectors  that  are  benefiting  from  India’s  increasing  domestic  consumption  and 
urbanization.4 The investment’s expected development impact benefits include job creation, 
technological innovation and adoption, support for homegrown entrepreneurs, and improvements 
in safeguards and corporate governance standards. 
 
II.  THE FUND 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
4.  Description. Tata Capital was established in 2007 as the alternative asset management 
subsidiary of Tata Sons Limited, the flagship holding company of the Tata Group.5 The Tata 
Group is the largest business conglomerate in India—it comprises more than 100 operating 
companies on six continents across 10 industry clusters (including information technology, steel, 
automobiles, consumer and retail, infrastructure, financial services, aerospace and defense, 
tourism and travel, telecom and media, trading, and investment)—and employs nearly 700,000 
people globally.6  
 
 
1  Asian Development Bank. 2015. Faster Approach to Small Nonsovereign Transactions. Manila. 
2  The fund is denominated in Indian rupee and accepts capital contributions in Indian rupee and United States (US) 
dollars. ADB will make its capital contributions and receive distributions in US dollars. For the purposes of this FAST 
report, references will be made to US dollars. International investors may also invest in an offshore feeder fund 
registered in Singapore, which will make investments in India via Tata Capital Growth Fund II LP. 
3  According to Tata Capital, lower middle market companies are expected to have revenues of at least ₹650 million 
with a track record of profitable operations. SMEs are a subset of lower middle market companies and are defined 
as companies with net tangible assets of at least ₹30 million according to the Bombay Stock Exchange’s listing 
criteria. Although not its primary focus, TCGF II may invest a portion of its capital in publicly traded securities 
(including private investments in public equity). 
4  ADB. 2019. Asian Development Outlook Supplement. Manila.

6  Tata Capital Limited. 2018. Private Placement Memorandum relating to Tata Capital Growth Fund II. Mumbai.

5.  TCGF II’s predecessor fund, Tata Capital Growth Fund I (TCGF I), is a 2011 vintage fund 
that raised about $240 million across both its domestic and offshore fund vehicles. The Mumbai-
based TCGF II investment team (which also managed TCGF I) includes managing partner Akhil 
Awasthi, partners Pramod Ahuja and Sanjay Chaudhary, and four investment professionals; and 
is supported by Tata Capital’s administrative staff in Singapore and Mumbai.  
 
6.  The TCGF II investment team brings substantial experience in private equity, banking, 
consulting, management, and operations, primarily in India. A. Awasthi has more than 20 years 
of experience in Indian private equity and has helped raise and manage four private equity funds 
with aggregate total commitments of about $1 billion, most recently with Tata Capital and 
previously as a partner at Baring Private Equity Asia. The following members of the investment 
team are sector experts: Sanjay Chaudhary (health care), Madhusudan Rajagopalan (financial 
services), Vishal Desai (manufacturing), and Ganesh Ramakrishnan (information technology); 
each has demonstrated deal origination, execution, and operational capabilities in prior roles. The 
majority of the team has worked together since 2010 when TCGF I was raised.  
 
7.  Investment identification. Tata Capital is one of 5 fund managers in India out of more 
than 50 that were assessed and evaluated by ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department, 
which considered TCGF II an attractive investment opportunity based on (i) its alignment with 
ADB’s  private  equity  fund  investment  guidelines,  including  management  by  a  seasoned 
investment team with solid private equity investment experience; and (ii) the strong performance 
of TCGF I. ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department first met with A. Awasthi in September 
2015 and subsequently interacted with him and his team on several occasions to track TCGF I’s 
progress and performance. In June 2018, Tata Capital commenced fundraising for TCGF II and 
approached ADB for support as it looked to broaden the fund’s institutional investor base.  
 
8.  The proposed investment in TCGF II will enable ADB to support the growth of well-
managed SMEs in India, which have traditionally relied on commercial banks or capital markets 
for funding. Stresses in India’s banking sector resulting from an increase in nonperforming assets 
since 2016 has resulted in banks favoring large corporates with the ability to pledge hard assets 
against loans; most SMEs lack this ability, and thus struggle to access appropriately priced bank 
financing. Private equity has consequently emerged as a critical source of growth capital for SMEs 
in India, which play a vital role in India’s economic development. For example, micro, small, and 
medium-sized enterprises constitute 95% of all industrial units in India, account for about 45% of 
industrial production, and generate 40% of its exports.7 By investing in funds such as TCGF II, 
ADB  can  increase  the  growth  capital  available  for  SMEs  and  support  sectors  such  as 
manufacturing and technology that have important development impacts, including generation of 
skilled and semiskilled employment and technological innovation and adoption in India.  
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
9.  TCGF II is targeting to raise $350 million to be invested in a portfolio of 10−12 established 
companies (mostly with revenues over $10 million). The fund will take primarily minority stakes, 
with investment expected to average $10 million−$35 million. The expected holding period for the 
fund’s investments is 3–5 years. TCGF II’s investment strategy and focus sectors are consistent 
with TCGF I, and include financial services, health care, manufacturing, and technology sectors.  
 
10.  The TCGF II investment team will seek to leverage Tata’s strong brand and network to

focus  on  minority  stakes  in  lower  middle-market  companies  and  SMEs  could  provide  a 
competitive advantage, because private equity funds in India are increasingly looking to invest 
larger amounts for majority stakes. This has resulted in TCGF II’s target segment consisting of 
companies that are relatively capital-starved given their limited access to bank financing.  
 
C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
 
11.  Ownership. Established as a trust under Indian laws, TCGF II is the Indian onshore 
master fund. The fund is sponsored by Tata Capital Limited, an Indian limited liability company 
that will act as the investment manager. Tata Trustee Company Limited, also an Indian limited 
liability company, will act as trustee to TCGF II. The offshore feeder fund is Tata Capital Growth 
Fund II LP, a limited partnership established in Singapore that will raise capital from investors 
outside India. The general partner of the offshore feeder fund is Tata Capital Growth II General 
Partners LLP, a limited liability partnership established in Singapore.8 Tata Capital Advisors 
Private Limited (regulated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore) is the investment manager of 
the offshore feeder fund. The offshore feeder fund will invest, through its wholly owned subsidiary, 
Alpha TC II Holding Private Limited, in the master fund. [This information has been removed as it 
falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].9 
 
12.  Integrity due diligence and enhanced tax integrity due diligence. ADB conducted 
integrity and enhanced tax integrity due diligence.10 [This information has been removed as it falls 
under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 
 
13.  Management. The TCGF II investment team (para. 5) is based in Mumbai. The seven 
investment professionals are responsible for sourcing and executing transactions, monitoring the 
portfolio, facilitating value addition to portfolio companies, and executing exit strategies.  
 
14.  Governance structure. The fund’s investment committee will consist of five members: (i) 
Rajiv Sabharwal (chief executive officer [CEO] of Tata Capital); (ii) the three TCGF II partners 
(para. 5), and (iii) Shigeki Usuki (CEO and investment committee representative of New Frontier 
Capital Management).11 The investment committee will make decisions by majority vote. 
  
15.  Tata Capital has established an advisory board for TCGF II currently comprising three 
representatives from investors of the fund. The advisory board will act as a consultative body to 
TCGF  II  with  regard  to  certain  governance  matters  affecting  its  investors  and,  in  specific 
circumstances set out in the fund documents, to approve such matters. In addition to the advisory 
board, Tata Capital has also established a conflict resolution committee (CRC) for TCGF II. The 
role of the CRC will be to assist in the resolution of specific conflicts of interests on acquisitions

16.  As with TCGF I, the fund investment team is expected to follow a multistage investment 
approval process. At the outset, the investment team will conduct initial deal evaluations and 
include pertinent details in a deal log; the team will then assess whether a deal falls within the 
scope of TCGF II’s investment strategy. If an investment strategy fit is confirmed, the team will 
prepare an initial screening memo (ISM) and an assessment of potential conflicts. The ISM 
includes transaction details, financial projections, and the investment team’s advice with respect 
to the proposed investment’s potential merits and risks.  
 
17.  After obtaining any necessary consent from the CRC, the investment team will further 
analyze the investment opportunity. Based on the ISM, the investment team will engage with the 
management of the target company and/or the financial intermediary that has introduced the deal. 
Based on initial diligence and management interaction, the investment team will then advise the 
investment manager whether the opportunity remains attractive in terms of the business potential, 
risks, and expected price. If the merits are confirmed, the investment manager will sign an 
indicative nonbinding term sheet. 
 
18.  Upon  execution  of  the  nonbinding  term  sheet,  the  investment  team  will  conduct 
comprehensive business diligence, including accounting, tax, and legal diligence using the 
services of reputable third-party accounting and legal firms, and subsequently prepare a final 
investment  recommendation  note,  which  it  will  present  to  the  investment  committee.  The 
committee  may  further  consult  the  CRC  before  making  a  final  investment  decision.  If  the 
investment is approved by the investment committee and, if required, the CRC, the investment 
team will execute the investment documents, and proceed to fund and close the transaction.

C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  Exit strategy. [This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to 
disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. Exits may be via strategic sale, 
initial public offering, sale to financial buyers, seller put and/or buyback, or secondary sale.  
 
23.  Reporting arrangements. ADB will require Tata Capital to provide (i) quarterly unaudited 
accounts of TCGF II; (ii) details of the investments purchased (including the cost of each such 
investment), sold or otherwise disposed of during the preceding quarter; (iii) an update on the 
general performance of the investments (including notification of any matters that would result in 
a material change to the prospects of the investments); (iv) details of any services provided by 
Tata Capital and its respective associated entities; (v) semiannual unaudited valuation reports; 
and (vi) annual audited accounts of the fund. ADB will require Tata Capital to provide an annual 
development effectiveness monitoring report for TCGF II. ADB will review this information and 
follow up if more information or clarifications are needed. If the information received raises issues 
that could impair the value of ADB’s investment in TCGF II, ADB could decide to put the fund on 
a watch list for more frequent review and closer attention. ADB will also require Tata Capital to 
report annually on TCGF II’s environmental and social safeguard issues in compliance with its 
environmental and social management system (ESMS). ADB will monitor the timing and quality 
of the safeguards reports and offer guidance if Tata Capital requires clarification regarding ADB’s 
safeguard requirements. 
 
D.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
24.  Private sector development. ADB’s investment in TCGF II is expected to encourage 
private sector investments in India from other like-minded institutional investors. It will also 
promote sustainable operations and governance best practices among the investee companies 
of the fund, and through a demonstration effect, set standards for other Indian corporates to 
emulate. By assisting in the growth of the fund’s investee companies, ADB’s investment can also 
promote the benefits of private equity as a funding option. 
 
25.  Capital mobilization. ADB’s participation can help mobilize additional capital from private 
and institutional investors in assisting the fund to reach its target size (para. 29), thereby achieving 
a multiplier effect on ADB's investment. Additionally, ADB will have the opportunity to co-invest in 
or lend to individual portfolio companies of TCGF II in sectors such as financial services and 
health care. 
 
26.  Setting  standards.  ADB  will  help  the  fund  develop  its  institutional  framework  for 
environmental and social safeguards, as well as encourage the investment team to sharpen its 
development  focus,  and  track  and  improve  developmental  indicators  within  its  investee 
companies. If this investment is approved, ADB will become the fund’s first development financial 
institution investor. 
 
27.  Gender equality. Tata Capital has agreed to adopt specific gender-inclusive actions for 
TCGF II (para. 46), which will be developed with ADB’s assistance. ADB’s participation may also 
promote gender equity in certain TCGF II investee companies.

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
37.  Impact. The proposed equity investment is expected to increase private equity funding for 
lower middle-market companies in India, contribute to the growth of the economy, create quality 
jobs, and improve business efficiency and transparency.  
 
38.  Outcome. The financial and social sustainability of private equity investments in India’s 
lower middle market companies demonstrated.  
 
39.  Outputs. The proposed equity investment will (i) establish TCGF II, (ii) invest fund capital 
into a portfolio of 10−12 companies within the proposed 4-year investment period, (iii) establish 
and implement new ESMS policies, and (iv) strengthen the fund’s gender-inclusive approach.  
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
40.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The proposed investment aligns 
with the operational priorities outlined in ADB’s Strategy 2030: growing private sector operations 
 
15 [This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].

7 
 
by expanding regional reach through private equity funds, supporting greater financial inclusion, 
strengthening the finance sector in capital markets, and widening geographical coverage.16 The 
proposed investment is also consistent with the country partnership strategy, 2018−2022 for India, 
which (i) highlights the need for recapitalization of the banking sector; (ii) includes support for 
affordable housing, financial inclusion, and the health sectors as strategic priorities; and (iii) 
focuses on the importance of gender equality.17  
 
41.  Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  proposed 
investment is consistent with the ADB Financial Sector Operational Plan 2011 and its subsequent 
review in 2017, which prioritizes support for finance sector development, including through 
investments in non-bank financial institutions and the housing finance sector;18 and the ADB 
Operational Plan for Health, 2015−2020, which highlights the need for private sector interventions 
to address quality, efficiency, and financing issues in the health sector.19 
 
42.  The  TCGF  I  portfolio  includes  several  investments  that  adhere  to  these  objectives 
including (i) Jana Small Finance Bank, which provides collateral-free loans to more than five 
million  women  (almost  100%  of  its  borrowing  base)  to  improve  their  income-generating 
capabilities; (ii) Star Health Insurance, which has provided health care insurance coverage to 
more than 7 million subscribers in India and also provides supplemental livelihoods to more than 
100,000 agents; (iii) Home First Finance Company, which provides affordable housing loans to 
more than 9,000 borrowers, including borrowers outside the formal banking system; and (iv) 
Nearex, a micro-payments company that has developed and sold more than 100,000 low-cost 
point-of-sales solutions to enable small merchants to accept digital and mobile payments.

investments; (ii) recruiting at least one female investment professional; and (iii) including at least 
one female member in TCGF II’s Value Optimisation Board.23 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
47.  Tata Capital was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice 
relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will 
ensure that the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, 
money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of  terrorism;  and  remedies  for  ADB  in  the  event  of 
noncompliance.

investment of up to $10,000,000 from the ordinary capital resources of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) in Tata Capital Growth Fund II in India, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

metadata.Subject: The transaction involves an equity investment of up to $10,000,000 in Tata Capital Growth Fund II (TCGF II) in India. The investment manager and sponsor of TCGF II is Tata Capital Limited (Tata Capital). Through TCGF II, Tata Capital proposes to invest primarily equity capital for minority stakes in a portfolio of 10−12 mainly lower middle-market companies in India, including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Focus sectors for the fund include financial services, health care, manufacturing, and information technology.
